title: Fractions & Equivalent Fractions for ADHD-Inclusive 5th Grade
description: A 40-minute math lesson on understanding and comparing fractions, with emphasis on ADHD-specific adaptations including chunked activities, movement integration, visible timers, and multi-sensory manipulatives. Also includes adaptations for ASD, Dyslexia, and Hearing Impairment students.
subject: Math
prompt: Create a 40-minute math lesson on understanding fractions and finding equivalent fractions for 5th graders. The class includes a student with ADHD who needs short chunked activities with movement breaks and visible timers, a student with autism who needs visual structure and predictability, a student with dyslexia who needs large print and reduced text density, and a student with hearing impairment who needs visual supports and captions. Align to Common Core State Standards (CCSS) and include hands-on manipulatives.

cached_plan.title: Fraction Foundations: Understanding and Comparing Fractions
cached_plan.subject: Math

objectives.text: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators by replacing given fractions with equivalent fractions.
Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole.
Model with mathematics: use fraction strips, number lines, and area models to represent fractional quantities.

mathematical_practices: MP1: Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them
MP7: Look for and make use of structure
curriculum_alignment.cluster: Use equivalent fractions as a strategy to add and subtract fractions

vertical_alignment.prerequisite_4th_grade: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.4.NF.A.1 -- Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to (n*a)/(n*b)

steps.title: Hook: The Pizza Problem
instructions: Display a colorful image of two pizzas: one cut into 4 slices, one cut into 8 slices.
Ask: 'Maria ate 2 slices of the first pizza. Jordan ate 4 slices of the second pizza. Who ate more?'
Give students 30 seconds of silent think time (display a visual timer).
Accept 3-4 student responses. Record on the whiteboard using fraction notation: 2/4 vs 4/8.
Reveal: 'They ate the SAME amount! These are called EQUIVALENT FRACTIONS.'
For Maya (ADHD): Announce the time frame upfront -- 'This part is just 5 minutes, then we use our hands!'
For Alex (ASD): Post the visual schedule for today's lesson next to the board.
activities: Think-Pair-Share: 'Who ate more pizza? Turn to your neighbor and explain why.'
assessment: Listen for students who immediately recognize equal amounts vs. those who focus on slice count.
Note which students can articulate WHY 2/4 = 4/8 (multiplicative reasoning).

steps.title: Guided Practice: Fraction Strips Discovery
instructions: Distribute fraction strip kits (pre-cut, color-coded paper strips) to each student.
Each kit contains: 1 whole (red), halves (orange), thirds (yellow), fourths (green), sixths (blue), eighths (purple), twelfths (pink).
Model the first comparison on the document camera: 'Place the 1/2 strip above two 1/4 strips. Do they line up?'
Students follow along at their desks, building fraction equivalencies hands-on.
After each comparison, students write the equivalency on a mini whiteboard.
For Maya (ADHD): The tactile manipulation keeps hands busy and focused; set a visible 8-minute timer.
For Alex (ASD): Provide a printed step-by-step instruction card: 'Step 1: Pick the strip. Step 2: Place it above. Step 3: Compare edges. Step 4: Write the equation.'
For Lucas (dyslexia): Fraction strips are color-coded (not text-dependent); mini whiteboard avoids handwriting fatigue.
For Sofia (hearing): Written instructions on the document camera alongside verbal explanation; visual hand signals for 'equal' and 'not equal'.
activities: Hands-on fraction strip manipulation at desks.
Write equivalencies on mini whiteboards: show on teacher count of 3.
assessment: Whiteboard check: Students hold up their boards showing the equivalency.
Walk the room during strip manipulation -- are students lining up edges accurately?

steps.title: Movement Break: Fraction Freeze Dance
instructions: Play upbeat music for 90 seconds. Students dance or move freely in designated area.
When music stops, call out a fraction: 'Show me 1/2!'
Students must freeze in a position that represents the fraction (e.g., one arm up = 1/2 of arms).
Repeat 3 times with different fractions: 1/2, 1/4, 3/4.
For Sofia (hearing): Use a visual music indicator (a projected color bar that pulses); flash the room light when music stops.
Display the fraction card visually in addition to calling it out verbally.
activities: Freeze dance with fraction body representations.
Students embody fractions using arms, legs, or body positioning.
assessment: Observe: Can students physically represent the fraction? (Informal, no-stakes.)
This is primarily a regulation break -- focus on re-engagement, not evaluation.

steps.title: Station Rotation: Equivalent Fractions Three Ways
instructions: Set up 3 stations (4 minutes each). Groups of 5-6 students rotate on a chime signal.
Station A -- Number Line: Plot fractions on a large number line (0 to 1). Find where 1/2, 2/4, and 4/8 land. Are they in the same spot?
Station B -- Area Model: Fold paper squares into halves, fourths, and eighths. Shade equivalent areas and compare by overlapping the papers.
Station C -- Multiplication Rule: Use a 'fraction machine' worksheet. Multiply numerator and denominator by the same number. Verify with fraction strips.
Post a visual timer at each station (4 minutes, auto-resetting).
For Maya (ADHD): Station rotation every 4 minutes prevents focus fatigue; physical movement between stations provides natural breaks.
For Alex (ASD): A visual rotation map shows the order: Station A -> B -> C. A laminated card at each station lists the 3 steps to complete.
For Lucas (dyslexia): All station instructions use large print (16pt), minimal text, and include worked examples with visuals.
For Sofia (hearing): Each station has written instruction cards; peer buddy assigned for verbal discussion moments.
activities: Station A: Plot and label fractions on the number line; circle fractions that land at the same point.
Station B: Fold, shade, and compare paper area models; glue completed models on a recording sheet.
Station C: Complete the 'fraction machine' -- input a fraction, multiply by 2, 3, 4 and verify each output is equivalent.
assessment: Station A: Check that equivalent fractions are plotted at the same point on the number line.
Station B: Verify shaded areas match when papers are overlaid.
Station C: Confirm multiplication is applied to BOTH numerator and denominator (common error: multiplying only the denominator).

steps.title: Whole-Class Problem Solving: Real-World Fractions
instructions: Return to whole group. Transition cue: two chimes.
Present 2 word problems on the projector (with visual supports and large text):
Problem 1: 'Emma's water bottle is 3/4 full. She pours half of it into her friend's bottle. What fraction did she pour?'
Problem 2: 'A recipe calls for 2/3 cup of flour. You only have a 1/6 cup measuring cup. How many scoops do you need?'
Solve Problem 1 together using fraction strips on the document camera.
Students attempt Problem 2 independently or with a partner (2 minutes), then share strategies.
For Maya (ADHD): Keep this segment brisk -- 2 problems only, announce 'Almost done! Last 7 minutes of math!'
For Alex (ASD): Provide both problems printed on his desk so he can follow along without looking up and down.
For Lucas (dyslexia): Problems displayed in large text with key numbers highlighted in color.
For Sofia (hearing): Problems displayed visually; teacher faces the class while explaining.
activities: Guided whole-class solving of Problem 1 with manipulatives.
Independent/partner attempt on Problem 2 with fraction strips available.
assessment: Check: Can students apply equivalent fraction reasoning to a real context?
Common error to watch for: treating 'half of 3/4' as subtraction (3/4 - 1/2) instead of multiplication (3/4 x 1/2).
Listen for students explaining their strategy to a partner -- verbal reasoning reveals depth of understanding.

steps.title: Exit Ticket & Reflection
instructions: Distribute differentiated exit tickets (3 questions each, multiple format options).
Option A (standard): 'Find 2 fractions equivalent to 3/6. Explain how you know they are equivalent.'
Option B (scaffolded): 'Complete: 1/2 = __/4 = __/8. Use your fraction strips to check.'
Option C (challenge): 'True or false: 5/10 = 3/6 = 7/14. Prove your answer using at least 2 methods.'
Option D (oral/visual): Record a 30-second voice explanation or draw a diagram showing two equivalent fractions.
After completing, each student writes on a sticky note: one thing they understood well and one thing they still wonder about.
Collect exit tickets and sticky notes. Preview: 'Tomorrow we use equivalent fractions to ADD fractions with different denominators!'
activities: Students select and complete their exit ticket format.
Reflection sticky note: 'I understand...' and 'I wonder...'
assessment: Sort exit tickets into 3 groups: solid understanding, partial, needs reteaching.
Target: 80% of students can identify at least one equivalent fraction correctly.
Sticky note analysis: identify common 'I wonder' themes to address in tomorrow's opening.

summary: Today we learn about EQUIVALENT FRACTIONS -- fractions that look different but mean the same amount.
We will use fraction strips, number lines, and paper folding to explore.
You will move between stations and get to dance!
At the end, you show what you learned your own way.

steps.title: The Pizza Problem
instructions: Look at the two pizzas on the screen.
Think: Who ate more pizza, Maria or Jordan?
Share your idea with your partner.
check_for_understanding: Can 2/4 and 4/8 be the same amount?
self_regulation_prompts: Just 5 minutes of sitting, then we get our fraction strips!

steps.title: Fraction Strips
instructions: Get your fraction strip kit from the materials bin.
Follow along: place the strips the teacher shows on the camera.
Compare the strips -- do they line up at the edges?
Write the matching fractions on your whiteboard.
check_for_understanding: Can you show me a fraction equal to 1/2 using your strips?
self_regulation_prompts: Keep your hands on the strips -- it is okay to fidget with them while you think!

steps.title: Dance Break!
instructions: Stand up and dance when the music plays!
When the music stops, FREEZE and show the fraction with your body!
Example: 1/2 = one arm up, one arm down.
self_regulation_prompts: Shake out all your wiggles! We have 12 more minutes of stations next.

steps.title: Station Rotation
instructions: You will visit 3 stations, 4 minutes each.
Station A: Number Line -- plot fractions and find the ones at the same spot.
Station B: Paper Folding -- fold and shade to compare fractions.
Station C: Fraction Machine -- multiply the top and bottom by the same number.
Follow the visual rotation map to know where to go next.
check_for_understanding: At Station C, what do you multiply to make an equivalent fraction?
self_regulation_prompts: You move every 4 minutes -- watch the timer at each station!

steps.title: Solving Together
instructions: Read the word problems on the screen (or your printed copy).
Solve Problem 1 with the whole class.
Try Problem 2 on your own or with a partner.
check_for_understanding: How many 1/6 scoops make 2/3 of a cup?
self_regulation_prompts: Almost done! Just 2 problems, then exit ticket.

steps.title: Show What You Know
instructions: Pick your exit ticket: write, draw, speak, or do the challenge version.
When done, write on a sticky: 'I understand...' and 'I wonder...'
Turn everything in to the teacher.
check_for_understanding: Can you find a fraction equal to 3/6?
self_regulation_prompts: You do not need to finish everything. Show your best thinking.

glossary: Fraction -- a number that shows part of a whole (like 1/2 or 3/4)
Numerator -- the top number in a fraction (how many parts you have)
Denominator -- the bottom number in a fraction (how many equal parts total)
Equivalent fractions -- fractions that look different but represent the same amount (like 1/2 and 2/4)
Number line -- a line with numbers placed at equal intervals, used to compare values
Area model -- a shape (like a rectangle) divided into equal parts to show a fraction
alternative_response_options: Write your answer with fractions and words
Draw a diagram (number line, area model, or fraction strips)

strategies: Lesson segmented into 6 chunks of 3-12 minutes each, never exceeding 12 minutes
Movement break (Fraction Freeze Dance) placed at the 16-minute mark to reset attention
Station rotation provides physical movement every 4 minutes during the longest activity
Visible countdown timers at every station and during every timed segment
Tactile manipulatives (fraction strips, paper folding) keep hands engaged throughout
Upfront time announcements: 'This part is X minutes, then we do Y'
Option to stand at a tall table during any seated work
Mini whiteboard reduces writing demand -- quick write-and-erase, lower stakes
do_not: Do not assign more than 8 minutes of seated listening without interaction
Do not require sustained silent individual work for more than 5 minutes
Do not take away movement break as a behavioral consequence
notes: Maya performs best with advance time warnings and clear end-of-segment signals
The fraction strip manipulation serves dual purpose: math learning + sensory regulation
Energy level typically dips around minute 20 -- the station rotation is strategically placed here

strategies: Visual schedule posted at the front with all 6 lesson phases and time durations
Laminated step-by-step instruction cards at each station (3 steps max per card)
Consistent transition signals: 2 chimes = return to whole group, 1 chime = move to next station
Visual rotation map shows station order: A -> B -> C with color coding
Predictable lesson structure maintained across math lessons for routine building
Printed copies of all projected content available at Alex's desk
do_not: Do not change station rotation order without 2-minute advance warning
Do not use ambiguous language in instructions ('figure it out' -> 'use your strips to check')
Do not require group work without structured roles (speaker, recorder, materials manager)
notes: Alex's pattern-recognition strength is well-suited to the multiplication rule at Station C
Provide a finished example at each station so Alex knows what the completed work looks like

strategies: All station instruction cards printed in 16pt OpenDyslexic font with extra line spacing
Word problems displayed with key numbers highlighted in bold color
Fraction strips are color-coded (not text-dependent) for visual-first learning
Mini whiteboards eliminate handwriting fatigue and reduce text production anxiety
Oral response option available for exit ticket and station reflections
Audio recording of station instructions available via QR code at each table
do_not: Do not require reading of fraction problems aloud in front of the class
Do not penalize number reversals (e.g., writing 2/4 as 4/2) without gentle redirection
Do not use worksheets with dense text blocks -- keep to bullet points and visuals
notes: Lucas excels at verbal reasoning -- encourage him to EXPLAIN his thinking orally, then translate to written if needed
The area model (paper folding) at Station B is particularly effective for visual-spatial learners with dyslexia

strategies: Written instruction cards at every station (not verbal-only directions)
Visual hand signals established for key concepts: 'equal' (two flat hands at same height), 'not equal' (hands at different heights), 'equivalent' (circular hand motion)
Teacher faces students when explaining and avoids speaking while writing on the board
Music for Fraction Freeze Dance accompanied by visual pulse indicator on projector; room light flash signals music stop
Peer buddy assigned for group discussion moments at stations
All projected content includes text alongside any verbal narration
do_not: Do not rely on auditory-only instructions for any station
Do not speak from the back of the room or while facing away from students
Do not use the chime as the sole transition signal -- pair with a visual cue (flashing light or raised card)
notes: Sofia excels with visual representations -- the number line and area model stations will be strong points
Ensure peer buddy at Station C can write the multiplication steps clearly for shared viewing

strategies: Multiple representations of the same concept: fraction strips (concrete), number line (pictorial), multiplication rule (abstract) -- CPA progression
Multiple expression modes: write, draw, speak, or manipulate to demonstrate understanding
Real-world context (pizza) to anchor abstract fraction concepts
Collaborative learning embedded in station work and pair sharing
Growth mindset language: 'I wonder...' sticky note normalizes having questions
do_not: Do not assume all students master fractions through a single representation
notes: The Concrete-Pictorial-Abstract (CPA) progression across stations is intentional and benefits all learners

media_requirements: Pizza comparison image (4-slice vs 8-slice, labeled) -- needs descriptive alt text
Fraction strip template PDF -- needs large-print variant (16pt) and pre-cut option for motor support
Number line template (0 to 1, with tick marks at halves, thirds, fourths, sixths, eighths) -- needs large-format wall version
Area model paper squares (pre-scored fold lines for motor support) -- needs high-contrast version
Station instruction cards -- needs OpenDyslexic font variant and audio QR code version
Exit ticket templates -- available in standard, scaffolded, challenge, and oral formats
Fraction Freeze Dance music track -- needs visual pulse indicator for hearing-impaired students
ui_recommendations: Timer widget: display a countdown timer on the main screen during all timed activities
Low-distraction mode: minimize on-screen elements during station rotation
Large-print toggle: boost all fraction notation to 24pt minimum for readability
Visual schedule sidebar: persistent panel showing current phase with progress indicator
Color-coding consistency: maintain the same colors for fraction families across all representations
visual_schedule_notes: Step 1: Pizza Problem (pizza slice icon) - 5 min
Step 2: Fraction Strips (colorful strips icon) - 8 min
Step 3: Dance Break! (dancing figure icon) - 3 min
Step 6: Show What You Know (star icon) - 5 min
teacher_review_points: Pre-cut fraction strips for students with motor difficulties (or have an aide pre-cut)
Verify that the visual pulse indicator for music works on the classroom projector
Print large-format station instruction cards (16pt OpenDyslexic) before class
Set up the 3 stations with all materials before students arrive
Test the chime + visual signal pairing for transitions
Have extra fraction strip kits available (students may lose pieces)

materials_needed: Fraction strip kits (class set, pre-cut, color-coded: whole/halves/thirds/fourths/sixths/eighths/twelfths)
Mini whiteboards and dry-erase markers (class set)
Document camera for modeling fraction strip comparisons
Large-format number line poster (0 to 1) for Station A
Paper squares for area model folding at Station B (pre-scored fold lines available)
Fraction Machine worksheets for Station C (standard and large-print versions)
Chime or bell for transition signals
Visual schedule cards (laminated, with lesson phases)
Station rotation map poster (color-coded: A=blue, B=green, C=purple)
Laminated step-by-step instruction cards for each station
Pizza comparison image (printed poster or projected)
Upbeat music track for Fraction Freeze Dance
Fraction flashcards for freeze dance moments
Exit ticket templates (4 format options: standard, scaffolded, challenge, oral)
Standing-height table or desk riser (at least 1)

approaching.description: Students who need additional scaffolding to understand fraction equivalence
modifications: Pre-labeled fraction strips with both the fraction and a visual bar representation
Scaffolded exit ticket: fill-in-the-blank with fraction strip verification
At Station C, provide a worked example alongside the blank 'fraction machine'
Pair with an on-level peer buddy during station rotation
Sentence frames for verbal explanations: 'I know ___ equals ___ because the strips line up at ___'

on_level.description: Students working at grade-level expectations for 5.NF.A.1
modifications: Standard fraction strip kit (labeled with fractions only)
Standard exit ticket: find equivalent fractions and explain reasoning
At Station C, complete the multiplication rule and verify with strips

advanced.description: Students ready for deeper fraction reasoning and generalization
modifications: Challenge exit ticket: prove or disprove 5/10 = 3/6 = 7/14 using at least 2 methods
At Station C, extend to simplifying fractions (reverse the multiplication: divide both by GCF)
At Station A, plot improper fractions and mixed numbers on an extended number line (0 to 2)
Create their own 'fraction puzzle' for a classmate: 'I am thinking of a fraction equivalent to 2/3 that has a denominator of 12. What am I?'

standards_aligned.description: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators using equivalent fractions
Solve word problems involving addition/subtraction of fractions
Model with mathematics using multiple representations

accessibility_adaptations: Chunked 3-12 min segments with visible timers for ADHD
Movement break with Fraction Freeze Dance for ADHD/all
Visual schedule and laminated instruction cards for ASD
Large print (OpenDyslexic 16pt) and oral options for Dyslexia
Visual signals, written instructions, and peer buddy for Hearing Impairment
scorecard.router_rationale: Math lesson with multi-accessibility requirements. Selected Sonnet for structured JSON output with strong pedagogical reasoning. Token estimate: ~2,100 input, ~4,200 output. Structured output weight: 0.85.
scorecard.time_saved_estimate: Approximately 3 hours of manual lesson planning, differentiation design, and accessibility adaptation work compressed into 7 seconds of AI pipeline execution.

payload.message: Generating lesson structure with 6 timed activities including station rotation
Applying ADHD-specific chunking strategy: max 12-minute segments with movement integration
Generating differentiated activities for approaching, on-level, and advanced tiers

payload.rationale: Score 91/100 exceeds the accept threshold (75). Strong ADHD-specific adaptations with movement integration, solid CPA progression for fraction understanding, and well-structured station rotation.
